Biological Effect: Increased APP transcription in a neuronal cell-based reporter system.

Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico algorithm suggested the variant is not damaging (PHRED-CADD = 10.41).

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: The S198P mutation increased the production of Aβ in cultured cells and in a transgenic mouse model of amyloidosis.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, no effect on Aβ42, Aβ40, and Aβ42/Aβ40.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Decreased aβ40 and Aβ42 without changing Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: No effect on Aβ42 or Aβ40 production in cells.

Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted to be probably damaging by PolyPhen-2 and tolerated by SIFT. PHRED-scaled CADD score > 20.

Biological Effect: In cells, no significant effect on Aβ40 or Aβ42 production.

Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico PHRED-CADD score >20, suggesting damaging effect.

Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted to be damaging in silico (PHRED-scaled CADD score >20).

Neuropathology: Unknown, but MRI showed atrophy of the hippocampus and of the temporal and parietal lobes in one case.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted to be damaging (PHRED-CADD = 22.8).

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but its PHRED-scaled CADD score was >20 suggesting a deleterious effect.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico data suggest a damaging effect (PHRED-CADD = 22.5).

Neuropathology: Unknown, but imaging revealed brain atrophy.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted to be probably damaging by PolyPhen-2, damaging by SIFT, and neutral by PROVEAN. PHRED-scaled CADD score > 20.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, neither Aβ40 nor Aβ42 production significantly affected.

Biological Effect: In cells, no significant effect on Aβ40 or Aβ42 production.

Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted to be probably damaging by in silico algorithms (PHRED-scaled CADD score > 20).

Neuropathology: One reported carrier of this variant had autopsy-confirmed AD.
Biological Effect: In cells, slight increase in Aβ40, but Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio not significantly different from controls.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, Aβ40 and Aβ42 production was similar to wildtype APP.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD, but not thought to be attributed to this variant.
Biological Effect: Decreased Aβ42 and Aβ40 in cells, without altering Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, Aβ40 secretion was slightly decreased with no change in Aβ42 secretion. Aβ42/Aβ40 was not significantly different from controls.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, reduced Aβ40 secretion, but did not significantly alter Aβ42 secretion nor the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: In cells, secreted less Aβ40, but Aβ42 secretion and the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio were not significantly altered.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but MRI showed atrophy of the frontoparietal cortex and hippocampus of one carrier.
Biological Effect: Unknown. Predicted in silico to be deleterious (PHRED-scaled CADD score >20).

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio, with a decrease in Aβ40 and an increase in Aβ42 secretion in a cellular assay.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42 and the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: One reported carrier of the variant had autopsy-confirmed AD.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ40 and Aβ42 secretion in cells, without significantly altering the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted deleterious in silico (PHRED-scaled CADD score = 25.8).

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico predicted to be deleterious (PHRED-scaled CADD score >20).

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: Aβ42, Aβ40, and the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio were not significantly different from those of cells expressing wildtype APP.

Neuropathology: Unknown, although MRI showed pronounced cerebral atrophy that included the hippocampus.
Biological Effect: Unknown. Although results were mixed, an integrative in silico prediction tool predicted damaging effects (PHRED-scaled CADD score >20).

Neuropathology: Generalized atrophy with sulcal widening and mild ventricular enlargement.
Biological Effect: Increased BACE1 cleavage resulting in elevated total Aβ, Aβ43, Aβ42, Aβ40, β-CTF, and multiple short N-terminal Aβ peptides. Synaptic alterations, defective endocytosis, altered axonal and soma-axon transport of APP and lipoproteins. Increased glucose metabolism, impaired glutamate transport in astrocytes.

Neuropathology: This variant is associated with minimal amyloid deposition. In three carriers, biopsies showed no Aβ, phospho-tau, or p62 pathology. Low sAPPβ and Aβ42 in CSF.
Biological Effect: Shifts APP processing towards non-amyloidogenic pathway, making APP a less-favorable substrate for β-secretase, resulting in less Aβ production. Also, Aβ peptides less prone to aggregation. Mutant Aβ peptides may have neuroprotective properties.

Neuropathology: Definite AD by CERAD criteria, with extensive deposition of Aβ and tau pathology (Braak stage VI). Cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Deposits contained high levels of Aβ40 and were noted to be unusually large, with few preamyloid deposits. Localization was frequently perivascular.
Biological Effect: In vitro, A673V shifts β-secretase processing of APP toward the amyloidogenic pathway and may increase Aβ aggregation; however, co-incubation of mutant and wild-type Aβ inhibits amyloidogenesis and toxicity.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Accelerated oligomerization kinetics and greater cytotoxicity than wild-type Aβ.

Neuropathology: Marked cortical atrophy, bilateral hippocampal atrophy, absence of focal cerebral infarction or hemorrhagic lesions in heterozygous carrier; small lacunar lesions in temporoparietal cortex and subcortical white matter in homozygous carrier.
Biological Effect: Accelerated oligomerization kinetics and greater cytotoxicity than wild-type Aβ.

Neuropathology: Unknown; amyloid-PET showed an initial increase followed by a decrease in amyloid burden;  SPECT imaging showed hypoperfusion in the bilateral parietal cortices and the left temporal lobe.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in conditioned media; increased secreted Aβ42 and Aβ40. Increased nucleation of Aβ aggregates/oligomers. Increased toxicity in vitro compared with wild-type Aβ42.

Neuropathology: Bilateral hippocampal volume loss; Cortical PiB uptake.
Biological Effect: Significantly increased total Aβ and Aβ42/Aβ40 levels; Shifts BACE1 cleavage toward the β-site. May also accelerate aggregation.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but in one case MRI revealed cerebral infarctions and leukoaraiosis and SWI showed microbleeds and amyloidosis.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but predicted in silico to be deleterious. PHRED-scaled CADD = 33.

Neuropathology: Unknown; MRI showed mild global brain atrophy without focal or vascular lesions. CSF biomarker profile consistent with AD, specifically elevated total tau and phosphorylated tau, along with reduced levels of Aβ1-42.
Biological Effect: Reduces APP cleavage by α-secretase. Reduced production of total sAPP and especially sAPPα. Increased Aβ40 and Aβ42. Alone, mutant Aβ was less toxic to neuroblastoma cells than wild-type Aβ42, but mixed in equimolar amounts with wild-type, toxicity increased. Alone, mutant Aβ formed predominantly low-n oligomers in vitro, but mixed with wild-type Aβ, it aggregated into high-n oligomers.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but imaging revealed white matter hyperintensities.
Biological Effect: Increased nucleation of Aβ aggregation in yeast cell-based assay. Also, inhibited lactylation, a post-translational modification that may be protective by inhibiting APP binding to BACE1and increasing APP degradation.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but MRI showed brain atrophy and PET showed cortical amyloid accumulation. CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but K687N (A>T) increased Aβ40 and Aβ42, and when mixed with wildtype Aβ, generated large oligomers; highly toxic in cells. Reduced degradation by neprilysin.

Neuropathology: In one case, CADASIL-like pathology with CAA was observed. In another, white matter damage and brain atrophy, particularly in the temporal lobe and hippocampus, were reported. CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD 4 years afterwards.
Biological Effect: Accelerated nucleation of Aβ aggregation in yeast cell-based assay.

Neuropathology: One reported carrier of this variant had autopsy-confirmed AD.
Biological Effect: Appears to largely eliminate non-amyloidogenic processing of APP and leads to the generation of rapidly aggregating Aβ peptides lacking amino acids 19-24. In mice, Aβ fibrils barely evoke a glial response.
Primary: Pagnon de la Vega et al., 2021

Mutation: (Uppsala deletion, APP Δ690-695, APP delta690–695, Uppsala APP deletion)

Neuropathology: Severe CAA and AD pathology. Numerous senile plaques; Dystrophic neurites; Congophilic angiopathy; Hemorrhagic infarction.
Biological Effect: Increased secreted Aβ42 and Aβ40 in CHO, HEK-293, and H4 cells. Increased β-CTF which correlated with endosomal dysfunction. Increased Aβ1-19 and Aβ5-40. Altered oligomerization, reduced aggregation.

Neuropathology: Unknown; remarkably low levels of amyloid by PiB-PET imaging in multiple carriers, but high tau-PET signal in one case.
Biological Effect: Enhanced oligomerization and nucleation of Aβ aggregates in vitro; altered production, secretion, localization, and clearance of Aβ peptides in cells; cognitive impairment, synaptic deficits, neuronal loss, glial activation, and tau hyperphosphorylation in animal models.

Neuropathology: Small to large hematomas, subarachnoid bleeding, scars with hemosiderin deposits, small infarcts, cortical calicifications; Aβ immunoreactivity in vessel walls and neuropil; Absence of neurofibrillary changes and neuritic plaques.
Biological Effect: Although reduced Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio and decreased Aβ42, the mutant peptide is toxic in cells and aggregates faster.

Neuropathology: Extensive amyloid deposition in the cerebral vasculature; Hemorrhages; Some diffuse plaques in brain parenchyma.
Biological Effect: Accelerates Aβ aggregation in vitro, increasing fibril formation; may alter APP processing.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD in several carriers. Plaques have a "targetoid: shape, with heterogenous truncated Aβ peptides in the center surrounded by Aβ42. Very low cortical PiB retention. No hemorrhage, but severe congophilic angiopathy.
Biological Effect: Increased propensity to form protofibrils, and at a faster rate. Aβ40 and Aβ42 production reduced or unchanged; increased Aβ5-29 and Aβ5-33. Decreased proteolytic degradation of Aβ by neprilysin. Neuronal toxicity.

Neuropathology: Extensive CAA with cortical, particularly occipital, calcifications and AD pathology; hemorrhagic lesions.
Biological Effect: Increased fibrillogenesis of the Aβ peptide; greater Aβ-induced toxicity; decreased α-secretase cleavage, increased Aβ5-29, Aβ5-33, Aβ1-19, Aβ1-33.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown. In silico algorithms yielded mixed results, but integrative PHRED-scaled CADD score was > 20, suggesting deleterious effect.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but in one case MRI showed widespread cerebral microangiopathy consistent with CAA and CSVD.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico analysis predicted damaging effect (PHRED-scaled CADD = 25.6).

Neuropathology: Severe CAA; Hemorrhages originating from affected vessels; “Vessel-within-vessel” morphology; Absence of parenchymal amyloid deposits and neurofibrillary tangles.
Biological Effect: Accelerated nucleation of Aβ aggregates in vitro

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42 secretion without significantly affecting the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Unknown, but in silico analysis predicted it is deleterious (PHRED-scaled CADD score >20).

Neuropathology: Variable: Generalized atrophy of the cerebral cortex; Widespread neurofibrillary tangles; Neuritic plaques; Variable cerebral amyloid angiopathy.
Biological Effect: In vitro, increased long forms of Aβ (Aβ45 and Aβ46); decreased short forms. Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio due to decreased Aβ40 secretion in cells. In vitro, promoted aggregation.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: Decreased Aβ42 and Aβ40 secretion in cells; no effect on Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio.

Neuropathology: Progressive cortical atrophy; White matter lesions.
Biological Effect: Increased longer Aβ peptides: Aβ42, Aβ46, Aβ48. Increased Aβ38+Aβ42+Aβ45+Aβ48; decreased Aβ40+Aβ43+Aβ46+Aβ49.

Neuropathology: Extensive neuronal loss; Diffuse gliosis; Neurofibrillary tangles; Amyloid plaques including diffuse "cloudy" plaques.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 and Aβ38/Aβ40 ratios, increased Aβ48 → Aβ45 → Aβ42 → Aβ38 pathway; decreased Aβ49 → Aβ46 → Aβ43 → Aβ40 pathway. Inefficient processing of Aβ; increased levels of membrane-anchored Aβ48.

Neuropathology: Progressive cortical atrophy; Hypometabolism.
Biological Effect: Decreased total Aβ; unchanged Aβ42; significantly decreased Aβ40.

Neuropathology: Hypoperfusion in the parieto-occipital region.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells and in vitro. Also increased Aβ38/40 ratio, and inhibited production of AICD50–99. ε-cleavage sites, particularly T48, appear to be affected.

Neuropathology: Extensive mixed neuropathology, including neurofibrillary changes, amyloid deposits, and Lewy bodies.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; decreased Aβ40 and AICD; increased Aβ1-38, Aβ1-39, Aβ1-42 and APP C-terminal fragments. Also, stalled γ-secretase-substrate complex tied to synaptic loss.

Neuropathology: Diffuse cortical atrophy, most prominant in the left anterior temporal lobe.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42(43)/Aβ40 ratio; increased Aβ42(43) and membrane-anchored Aβ48. Decreased Aβ48 → Aβ45 → Aβ42 → Aβ38 pathway.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 and Aβ38/Aβ42 ratios and increased levels of longer Aβ peptides, including membrane-anchored Aβ49. Decreased total Aβ and AICD. Decreased ε-cleavage and shifted towards the Aβ48 → Aβ45 → Aβ42 → Aβ38 pathway. Stalled the γ-secretase-substrate complex in the membrane.

Neuropathology: Unknown; MRI showed mild bilateral hippocampal atrophy.
Biological Effect: Unknown; predicted damaging in silico (PHRED-scaled CADD score > 20).

Neuropathology: In one case, neuropathology was consistent with AD.
Biological Effect: In vitro, increased long Aβ peptides (Aβ48, 46, 45), ε-cleavage, Aβ48 pathway. In cells, increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio. Altered endocytosis and transport of lipoproteins and APP to axons, possibly via increased β-CTF.

Neuropathology: Variable: AD plaques and tangles with some reports of mild to severe CAA, cortical and brainstem Lewy bodies, TDP-43 pathology in hippocampus and amygdala, striatal amyloid deposition.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; increased Aβ42; little effect on Aβ40. In yeast system, reduced ε-cleavage. Mutant iPSC-neurons induced a dampened DAM signature in microglia.

Neuropathology: Unknown; MRI in the Japanese family showed relatively minor atrophic changes in the bilateral hippocampus and cerebral cortices.
Biological Effect: Increased total Aβ, Aβ42, Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; decreased Aβ40. Increased Aβ48 → Aβ45 → Aβ42 → Aβ38 pathway; decreased Aβ49 → Aβ46 → Aβ43 → Aβ40 pathway. Inefficient processing of longer, membrane-anchored peptides: increases in Aβ48, Aβ46, and Aβ45. ε-cleavage also increased.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD in at least one case.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; increased total Aβ, Aβ48, Aβ46, Aβ45, Aβ42, and Aβ38; decreased Aβ40. Increased long, membrane-anchored Aβ peptides. Increased ε-cleavage, including cleavage at a novel site.

Neuropathology: Unknown; atrophy of the temporal lobes by MRI.
Biological Effect: Increased levels of membrane-anchored Aβ49 and Aβ46; increase in the Aβ49 → Aβ46 → Aβ43 → Aβ40 pathway over the Aβ48 → Aβ45 → Aβ42 → Aβ38 pathway. Favors ε-cleavage at Aβ49 over Aβ48. Stalls γ-secretase-APP complex which appears to be toxic per se.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: In a heterologous expression system, the T719N mutation led to increased levels of Aβ42 and an elevated Aβ42:Aβ40 ratio, compared with wild-type APP.

Neuropathology: Unknown; MRI of the proband at age 42 showed moderate cerebral atrophy, especially in the hippocampus.
Biological Effect: Increase Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; increased Aβ42; unchanged Aβ40; More phospho-tau.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ48 levels, reduced Aβ48 trimming. Decreased ε-cleavage; Aβ49 production nearly abrogated.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42 and decreased Aβ40 levels resulting in an increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but in one carrier, MRI revealed mild global brain atrophy and enlargement of the ventricles.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio and Aβ42 levels in cultured cells.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD in one carrier.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio; increased Aβ42; decreased Aβ40 in cells.

Neuropathology: Not applicable.
Biological Effect: Increased Aβ42 moderately, without significantly altering the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in cells.

Neuropathology: Unknown; at least one affected deletion carrier had neuropathology consistent with AD.
Biological Effect: Unknown; deletion does not appear to affect APP splicing.

Neuropathology: Unknown; imaging showed an ischemic stroke in the right middle cerebral artery and hematomas in the right temporal and parietal lobes. MRI showed numerous cortical microbleeds and  white-matter hyperintensities.
Biological Effect: Unknown. Failed to reach commonly used threshold for in silico deleteriousness classification (PHRED-scaled CADD score = 19.09).

Neuropathology: Unknown; imaging revealed multiple subarachnoid hemorrhages and hematomas in the temporal, frontal, and parietal regions of the cortex, as well as diffuse superficial siderosis, cortical microbleeds, and white matter hyperintensities.
Biological Effect: This deletion of two base pairs (TA) occurs in a highly conserved region of  the UTR. When cloned into a luciferase reporter, the variant increased APP expression (~1.5-fold over WT). APP upregulation was at least partially attributable to changes in miRNA binding.

Neuropathology: Unknown; at least two mutation carriers had hemorrhages and microbleeds consistent with CAA. However, this variant has also been detected in controls.
Biological Effect: Unknown.

Neuropathology: In one carrier, examination of the brain at autopsy revealed neuropathology consistent with AD and CAA.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood. This duplication includes a single gene: APP.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but an MRI scan of one carrier revealed probable CAA.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood. This duplication includes a single gene: APP.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CT and MRI scans of 4 affected and 6 asymptomatic carriers revealed white matter lesions or some form of vascular alteration.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood. This duplication includes a single gene: APP.

Neuropathology: Consistent with AD and CAA.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood. This duplication includes a single gene: APP.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology unknown, but MRI of one carrier revealed CAA with 2 intracerebral hemorrhages, 6 cerebral microbleeds, and cortical superficial siderosis.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Consistent with severe CAA in 1 carrier and probable CAA detected by MRI in another. Absence of neurofibrillary tangles.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but MRI of one carrier revealed probable CAA with 3 intracerebral hemorrhages and 13 cerebral microbleeds.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: In one carrier, neuropathology was consistent with AD with severe CAA and LBD. CAA and Lewy bodies were widespread. MRI of 3 carriers suggests neuropathology is heterogenous.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Consistent with AD and CAA in one case, and MRI revealed probable CAA in another.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD and severe CAA in cortex, insula, and basal ganglia. Also, Lewy bodies in the amygdala, locus niger, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and entorhinal cortex.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD and MRI revealed probable CAA in one carrier.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD in one carrier. MRI showed no signs of CAA.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD in one carrier.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood. This duplication includes a single gene: APP.

Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD and severe CAA in two carriers.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology was consistent with AD and severe CAA in two carriers.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology was consistent with AD and severe CAA in 3 carriers.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but hypoperfusion was seen in cortex of 1 carrier and was diffuse in another. MRI showed parieto-occipital and frontal white matter changes in the former. Atrophy was severe in the parieto-temporal cortices of both carriers.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD and severe CAA in 3 carriers.
Biological Effect: Data unavailable for this specific duplication, but pooled data reveal APP duplications increase APP expression by ~1.5 in blood.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD. MRI of one carrier showed mild cortical atrophy without cerebrovascular alterations.
Biological Effect: Levels of APP mRNA in the proband's blood were elevated ~1.5-fold.

Neuropathology: Unknown, but CSF biomarkers were consistent with AD and brain imaging revealed sucbcortical white matter microbleeds and hyperintensities in one carrier.
Biological Effect: Increased APP mRNA in blood ~1.5-fold.

Neuropathology: CAA observed in a non-genotyped family member. One carrier had brain vascular alterations as revealed by MRI and CSF biomarkers (Aβ42, Aβ40, tau, phospho-tau) consistent with AD.
Biological Effect: APP mRNA levels in blood were increased 2-fold in the proband.

Neuropathology: Neuropathology consistent with AD, usually developing by age 40 and often accompanied by CAA. Cerebrovascular disease appears to correlate with the severity of amyloid and tau pathologies, suggesting it is a core feature of DSAD tied to AD progression.
Biological Effect: APP overexpression, possible modification of pathology/vulnerability by increased expression of other genes on chromosome 21.
